question.text:
In a practical unit if the unit of mass becomes double
and that of unit of time becomes half, then 8 joule will be equal to
............. unit of work.

solution.text:
Work → [ML2T–2]

n1v1 = n2v2

$$\frac{(8)M_{1}L_{1}^{2}T_{1}^{2}}{M_{2}L_{2}^{2}T_{2}^{2}} = n_{2}$$

$$\mathbf{\Rightarrow}\mathbf{\ \ \ }8\mathbf{\ }\left\lbrack \frac{M_{1}}{M_{2}} \right\rbrack\left\lbrack \frac{L_{1}}{L_{2}} \right\rbrack^{2}\left\lbrack \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}} \right\rbrack^{- 2} = n_{2}$$

$$\mathbf{\Rightarrow}\mathbf{\ \ \ }8\mathbf{\ }\left\lbrack \frac{M_{1}}{{2M}_{2}} \right\rbrack\left\lbrack \frac{L_{1}}{L_{2}} \right\rbrack^{2}\left\lbrack \frac{{2T}_{1}}{T_{2}} \right\rbrack^{- 2} = n_{2}$$

⇒ $8 \times \ \frac{1}{2} \times \ \frac{1}{4} = n_{2}$

⇒ $\boxed{n_{2} = 1}$

So, unit of 8 joule = $\boxed{1 \times \ new\ units}$

$\lbrack G\rbrack = \frac{\left\lbrack MLT^{- 2} \right\rbrack\left\lbrack L^{2} \right\rbrack}{\left\lbrack M^{2} \right\rbrack}$  = [M−1L3T−2]

question.text: Given that $:y = A\sin\left\lbrack \left( \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \right)\ (ct - x) \right\rbrack$ where, y and x are measured in metre. Which of the following statements is true

d.text: The unit of λ is same as that of x and A
The unit of λ is same as that of x but not of A
The unit of c is same as that of $\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}$
The unit of (ct−x) is same as that of $\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}$

solution.text: Here, $\frac{2\pi}{\lambda}(ct - x)$ is dimensionless. Hence, $\frac{ct}{\lambda}$ is also dimensionless and unit of ct is same as that of x. Therefore, unit of λ is same as that of x. Also unit of y is same as that of A, which is also the unit of x.

question.text: A physical quantity U is given by the relation $U = \frac{B^{2}}{2\mu_{0}}$ here, B= magnetic field strength and μ0= magnetic permeability of vacuum then U Reference

solution.text:

$= \frac{N}{m^{2}} = \frac{Nm}{m^{3}} = \frac{J}{m^{3}}$

= energy per unit volume = energy density

question.text: Dimensions of resistance in an electrical circuit, in terms of dimension of mass M, of length L, of time T and current I, would be

(∵ Potential difference is equal to work doen per unit charge) So, dimensions of

$$R = \frac{\lbrack Dimensions\ of\ work\rbrack}{\lbrack Dimensions\ of\ charge\rbrack\lbrack Dimensions\ of\ current\rbrack}$$

$\ = \frac{\left\lbrack ML^{2}T^{- 2} \right\rbrack}{\lbrack IT\rbrack\lbrack I\rbrack} = \left\lbrack ML^{2}T^{- 3}I^{- 2} \right\rbrack$ .

question.text: The circular divisions of shown screw gauge are 50. It moves 0.5 mm on main scale in one rotation. The diameter of the ball is

solution.text:
Zero error $= 5 \times \frac{0.5}{50} = 0.05\ mm$

Actual measurement

$$= 2 \times 0.5\ mm + 25 \times \frac{0.5}{50} - 0.05\ mm$$

 = 1 mm + 0.25 mm − 0.05 mm = 1.20 mm.

question.text: Two full turns of the circular scale of a screw gauge cover a distance of 1 mm on its main scale. The total number of divisions on the circular scale is 50. Further, it is found that the screw gauge has a zero error of  − 0.03 mm. While measuring the diameter of a thin wire, a student notes the main scale reading of 3 mm and the number of circular scale divisions in line with the main scale as 35. The diameter of the wire is

solution.text:
Least count $= \frac{Pitch}{No.\ of\ div.\ in\ circular\ scale}$

$$= \frac{0.5}{50} = 0.01\ mm$$

Actual reading  = 0.01 × 35 + 3 = 3.35 mm

Taking error into consideration

 = 3.35 + 0.03 = 3.38 mm .

question.text: The least count of a stop watch is $\frac{1}{5}$ second. The time of 20 oscillations of a pendulum is measured to be 25 seconds. The maximum percentage error in the measurement of time will be

solution.text:
Least count = ∆T = $\frac{1}{5}s =$ 0.2 s

T = 25 s

Percentage error = $\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}T}{T} \times 100\% = \frac{0.2}{25} \times 100\% = 0.8\%$

question.text: The values of two resistors are R1 = (6 ±0.3) kΩ and R2 = (10 ±0.2)kΩ. The percentage error in the equivalent resistance when they are connected in parallel is

solution.text:
R1 = (6±0.3)kΩ, R2 = (10±0.2)kΩ

$$R_{parallel} = \frac{R_{1}R_{2}}{\left( R_{1} + R_{2} \right)}$$

Let (R1+R2) = x

$$\Rightarrow \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ R_{P} = \frac{R_{1}R_{2}}{x}$$

Taking log of both sides

                                ln RP = ln R1 + ln R2 − ln x

$$\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}R_{P}}{R_{P}} = \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}R_{1}}{R_{1}} + \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}R_{2}}{R_{2}} + \left( - \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}x}{x} \right)$$

$$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mathrm{\Delta}x_{mean} = \frac{0.3 + 0.2}{2} = 0.25\ \Omega$$

$$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ R_{mean} = \frac{6 + 10}{2} = 8\ \Omega$$

$$\therefore\ \ \ x = \frac{6 + 10}{2} = 8\ \Omega$$

$$\Rightarrow \frac{\ \mathrm{\Delta}x}{x} = \frac{0.25}{8}$$

$$\therefore Total\ error = \frac{0.3}{6} + \frac{0.2}{10} + \frac{0.25}{8}$$

 = 0.05 + 0.02 + 0.03125 = 0.10125

$$\therefore\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}R_{P}}{R_{P}} = 10.125\%$$

A physical quantity A is related to four observables a, b, c and d as follows

$\ A = \frac{a^{2}b^{3}}{c\sqrt{d}}$

question.text: If K denotes coefficient of thermal conductivity, d the density and c the specific heat, the unit of X, where X = K/dc will be

solution.text:
We know that

$$Q = \frac{KA\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right)t}{d}$$

$$\Rightarrow \ \ \ \ \ \ K = \frac{Qd}{A\left( \theta_{1} - \theta_{2} \right)t}$$

So, the unit of $K = \frac{cal\ \times metre}{{metre}^{2}\ \times \ K\ \times \ sec}$

$$= \frac{cal}{m}.K\ .\sec\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(i)$$

And density $d = \frac{m}{V},$ where m= mass, V= volume.

So, the unit of $d = \frac{kg}{m^{3}}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(ii)$

Also, we know that Q = mcΔθ

$$\Rightarrow \ \ \ c = \frac{Q}{m\ .\ \mathrm{\Delta}\theta}$$

So, the unit of $c = \frac{cal}{kg\ .K}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots(iii)$

Hence, the unit of $X = \frac{K}{dc}$

On putting the values of unit from Eqs. (i), (ii) and (iii), the unit of

$$\ X = \frac{cal/mK - sec}{{kg/m}^{3} \times cal/kg\ .K}$$

⇒       = m2/s

So, the unit of X in CGS system is cm2s−1

= $\ \frac{M^{1}L^{- 2}T^{- 2}}{L^{3}}\ = \ \ M^{1}L^{- 1}T^{- 2}$ = Energy density

question.text:
The length of a simple pendulum is about 100 cm known to
an accuracy of 1 mm. Its period of oscillation is 2s determined by
measuring the time for 100 oscillations using a clock of 0.1 s
resolution. What is the accuracy in the determined value of g?

solution.text:
Time period of a simple pendulum

$$T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{8}}\ $$

$$Or\ \ g = \frac{4\pi^{2}L}{T^{2}}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots.(i)$$

Differentiating Eq. (i), we have

$$\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}g}{g} = \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}L}{L} + \frac{2\mathrm{\Delta}T}{T}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ldots\ldots\ldots(ii)$$

Given, L=100 cm, T=2s,

$$\mathrm{\Delta}T = \frac{0.1}{100} = 0.001s,\ $$

ΔL = 1mm = 0.1 cm

Substituting the in Eq. (ii), we have

$$\therefore\left| \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}g}{g} \right|_{\max\ } = \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}L}{L} + \frac{2\mathrm{\Delta}T}{T}$$

$$= \frac{0.1}{100} + 2 \times \frac{0.001}{2}$$

Thus, maximum percentage eror

$$\left| \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}g}{g} \right|_{\max\ } \times 100 = \left( \frac{0.1}{100} \times 100 \right) + \left( \frac{2 \times 0.001}{2} \times 100 \right)$$

 = 0.1% + 0.1% = 0.2% .

question.text: A person starts walking and comes back to its initial position after 2 h, then which of the following quantity is zero?

solution.text:
The displacement will be zero because the initial and final positions are the same. 

The path length will be non-zero. 

The time will keep on increasing.

Average speed will be non-zero too.

Average speed $= \frac{total\ distance}{total\ time}$

The total distance and total time taken are both non-zero, so average speed will also be non-zero.

question.text: A particle starts from rest and traverse a distance 2x with uniform acceleration, then moves uniformly over a further distance 4x and finally comes to rest after moving a further distance 6x under uniform retardation. Let t1,t2 and t3 be the time taken by the particles to cover the distance 2x, 4x and 6x respectively. Let v be the velocity of the particle at B ie, maximum velocity. The particle moves with uniform acceleration from A to B.

For motion for A to B.

Average velocity $= \frac{0 + v}{2} = \frac{v}{2}$

Time taken, $t_{1} = \frac{2x}{v/2} = \frac{4x}{v}$

Particle moves with uniform retardation from C to D.

Time taken , $t_{3} = \frac{6x}{(0 + v)/2} = \frac{12x}{v}$

Total time  = t1 + t2 + t3

$$= \frac{4x}{v} + \frac{4x}{v} + \frac{12x}{v} = \frac{20x}{v}$$

$$v_{av} = \frac{2x + 4x + 6x}{20x/v} = \frac{12v}{20}\ $$

or $\frac{v}{v} = \frac{12}{20} = \frac{3}{5}$.

question.text:
A 1 kg stationary bomb is exploded in three parts having
mass 1 : 1 : 3 respectively. parts having same mass move in
perpendicular direction with velocity 30 m/s, then the velocity of

solution.text:
Apply conservation of linear momentum

Total momentum before explosion = total momentum after explosion

$0 = \frac{m}{5}v_{1}\widehat{i} + \frac{m}{5}v_{2}\widehat{j} + \frac{3m}{5}{\overrightarrow{v}}_{3};$

$\frac{3m}{5}{\overrightarrow{v}}_{3} = - \frac{m}{5}\left\lbrack v_{1}\widehat{i} + v_{2}\widehat{j} \right\rbrack$

${\overrightarrow{v}}_{3} = \frac{- v_{1}}{3}\widehat{i} - \frac{v_{2}}{3}\ \widehat{j}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \because v_{1} = v_{2} = 30\ m/sec.$

${\overrightarrow{v}}_{3} = - 10\widehat{i} - 10\widehat{j};v_{3} = 10\sqrt{2}\ m/sec$.

question.text:

solution.text:
P(initial) = P(final)

0 = n × m × u + (M – n × m) × v

where: n=10, m = 10g =0.01kg, u = 800m/s,

M = 100kg

0 = 10 × 0.01kg × 800m/s + (100kg −10 × 0.01kg) × v

V = −$\ \frac{80kgm/s}{99.9kgm/s}$

V = −0.8m/s

Then: F=$\ \frac{\Delta P\ }{\Delta t}$​ =$\frac{10\ \times \ 0.01kg\ \times \ 800m/s}{5s}$​ = 16N

question.text: The momentum p (in kg m/s) of a particle is varying with time t (in s) as p = 2 + 3t2. The force acting on the particle at t = 3 s will be

At t = 3s

question.text: A 5000 kg rocket is set for vertical firing. The xhaust speed is 800 ms−1. To give an initial upward acceleration of 20 ms−2 the amount of gas ejected per second to supply the needed thrust will be (g = 10 m s-2)

solution.text:
Given that,

Mass of rocket m = 5000Kg

Acceleration a = 20m/s2

Speed v = 800m/s

g = 10m/s2

Now, thrust force on the rocket

$F_{t} = v_{r}\left( \frac{- dm}{dt} \right)$

Net force on the rocket

Fnet = Ft − W

$ma = v_{r}\left( \frac{- dm}{dt} \right) - mg$

$\left( \frac{- dm}{dt} \right) = \frac{m(g + a)}{v_{r}}$

Rate of gas ejected per second

$\left( \frac{- dm}{dt} \right) = \frac{5000(10 + 20)}{800}$

$\frac{- dm}{dt} = 187.5\ kg/s$

Hence, the amount of gas ejected per second is 187.5 kg/s

question.text: Two blocks of masses 2 kg and 4 kg are hanging with the help of massless string passing over an ideal pulley inside an elevator. The elevator is moving upward with an acceleration $\frac{g}{2}$ . The tension in the string connected between the blocks will be (Take g = 10 m/s2).

solution.text:
As the elevator is going upward with acceleration$\frac{9}{2}$ so 2 log block with focal$2 \times \frac{9}{2}\ $ downwards

& 4log block with focal $4 \times \frac{9}{2}$ downward as a prudes force

⇒ weight + pruedo  − T = ma

or 4g + 2gT = 4a  −  −  −  −  − − (1)

 ⇒ T − (2g+9) = 2a i.e. f = ma

 or T−3g=2a -------- (2)

(1) × 1 (2) × 2 we get 69 − T − (2T−69) =  + a + a

or 6g − 3T + 6g = 0

$$T = \frac{12g}{3} = 4g = 40N$$

question.text: A bucket full of water weighs 5 kg, it is pulled from a well 20 m deep. There is a small hole in the bucket through which water leaks at a constant rate of 0.2kgm−1. The total work done in pulling the bucket up from the well is (g = 10ms−2)

solution.text:
The weight of bucket when it has been pulled up a distance x is (5-0.2x).

Hence, the required work is

W = ∫x = 20x = 0−(5−0.2x) × 10 × dx

$= \lbrack 50x\rbrack_{x = 0}^{x = 20} - \left\lbrack 2\frac{x^{2}}{2} \right\rbrack_{x = 0}^{x = 20}$

W = 50 × 20 − (20)2 = 600J.

question.text:
Particle is released from a height H. At a certain
height from the ground its K.E is twice the P.E. The height & speed

solution.text:
Total mechanical energy =mgH

2PE + PE = mgH

∴v = 2$\sqrt{\frac{9H}{3}}$​​ is the velocity at that instant

A ball is dropped from height 20 m. If coefficient of
restitution is 0.9, what will be the height attained after first
bounce?

solution.text:
If a body falls from height h, then from equation of motion we know that it will hit the ground with a velocity say u=$\sqrt{2gh}$ which is also the velocity of approach here. Now, if after collision it gains a height h1 then again by equation of motion $v = \sqrt{2gh}$, which is also the velocity of separation .so, by definition of e,

$e = \sqrt{\frac{2gh_{1}}{2gh}\ }or\ \ h_{1} = e^{2}h$

Given, h=20 m, e=0.9

∴ height attained after first bounce

h1 = (0.9)2 × 20

 = 0.9 × 0.9 × 20

         = 16.2

question.text: A man of mass 50 kg is standing in an elevator. If elevator is moving up with an acceleration $\frac{g}{3}$ then work done by normal reaction of floor of elevator on man when elevator moves by a distance 12 m is (g = 10 m/s2)

solution.text:

$N = m\left( \frac{4g}{3} \right) = \frac{50 \times 4 \times 10}{3}$

Now W = F × d = N × d=

$W = \frac{50 \times 4 \times 10}{3} \times 12 = 8000\ J$

question.text: A particle of mass m1 is moving with a velocity v1 and another particle of mass m2 is moving with a velocity v2. Both of them have the same momentum but their different kinetic energies are E1 and E2 respectively. if m1 > m2 then

solution.text:
Kinetic energy = $\frac{p^{2}}{2m}$

$\therefore\frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}} = \frac{p_{1}^{2}/2m_{1}}{p_{2}^{2}/2m_{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{E_{1}}{E_{2}} = \frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}}\ as\ m_{1}m_{2}$ >

∴ E1 < E2.

question.text: A stationary particle explodes into two particles of masses m1 and m2 which move in opposite directions with velocities v1 and v2. The ratio of their kinetic energies E1/E2 is

As m = 2 kg and a = 2 ms−2

question.text:
A bucket of water 35 kg is lifted from a well 10 m deep
using metal chain of 10 kg in 20 sec. The power needed is

A body is moved along a straight line by a machine
delivering a constant power. The distance moved by the body in time ‘t’
is proportional to

solution.text:
We know that F × v = Power

∴ F  × v = c     where c = constant

$\therefore m\frac{dv}{dt}\ \times v = c\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \left( \therefore F = ma = \ \frac{mdv}{dt} \right)$

$\therefore m\int_{0}^{v}{vdv = c\int_{0}^{t}{dt\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \therefore\frac{1}{2}}}\ {mv}^{2\ } = ct$

$\therefore v = \sqrt{\frac{2c}{m}}\ \times \ t^{1/2}$

$\therefore\ \ \frac{dx}{dt}\ \ \sqrt{\frac{2c}{m}}\ \times t^{1/2}\ \ \ where\ v = \frac{dx}{dt}$

$\therefore\int_{0}^{x}{dx = \sqrt{\frac{2c}{m}}}\ \times \ \int_{0}^{t}t^{1/2}dt$

$x = \ \sqrt{\frac{2c}{m}}\ \times \frac{{2t}^{\frac{3}{2}}\ }{3} \Rightarrow \ \ x\ \propto \ t^{\frac{3}{2}}$

question.text: A particle moves in a straight line with retardation proportional to its displacement. Its loss of KE for any displacement x is proportional to

question.text: A block C of mass mis moving with velocity v0and collides elastically with block Aof mass m and connected to another block Bof mass 2m through spring constant k.What is k if x0 is compression of spring when velocity of A and B is same ?

solution.text:
Using conservation of linear momentum, we have

mv0 = mv + 2mv

Or $v = \frac{v_{0}}{3}$

Using conservation of energy, we have

$\frac{1}{2}mv_{0}^{2} = \frac{1}{2}kx_{0}^{2} + \frac{1}{2}(3m)v^{2}$

Where x0=compression in the spring,

$\therefore mv_{0}^{2} = kx_{0}^{2} + (3m)\ \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{9}$

Or $kx_{0}^{2} = \ mv_{0}^{2} - \frac{mv_{0}^{2}}{3}$

Or $kx_{0}^{2} = \frac{2mv_{0}^{2}}{3}$

$\therefore k = \frac{2mv_{0}^{2}}{3x_{0}^{2}}$ .

question.text: Two springs p and Q of force constants kp and $k_{Q}\left( k_{Q} = \frac{k_{p}}{2} \right)$ are stretched by applying forces of equal magnitude. If the energy stored in Q is E,then the energy stored inP is

solution.text:
Givenkp = 2kQ

By stretched spring gain get energy

$E = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ (\because F = kx)$

OR $E = \frac{1}{2}\ \frac{F^{2}}{K}$

∵For spring P

$$E_{P} = \frac{1}{2}\ \frac{F^{2}}{K_{P}}$$

∵For spring Q

$E_{Q} = \frac{1}{2}\ \frac{F^{2}}{K^{Q}}$

$\frac{E_{P}}{E_{Q}} = \frac{K_{Q}}{K_{P}} = \frac{1}{2}$

$E_{P} = \frac{E_{Q}}{2} = \frac{E}{2}$

solution.text:
If W1= work done by applied force

W2= work done against friction then applying work energy theorem

W1 − W2= PE +KE (at the top)

$F \times s - W_{2} = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mv^{2}$

$100 \times 12 - W_{2} = 50 \times 10 \times 2 + \frac{1}{2} \times 50 \times 2^{2}$

1200 − W2 = 1100

W2= 100 J.

question.text:
A 2 kg block slides on a horizontal floor with a speed
of 4 m/s. It strikes an uncompressed spring, and compresses it till the
block is motionless. The kinetic friction force is 15 N and spring
constant is 10,000 N/m. The spring compresses by

solution.text:
Let the block compress the spring by x before stopping. Kinetic energy of the block = (P.E. of compressed spring) + work done against friction.

$\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times {(4)}^{2} = \ \frac{1}{2} \times 10,000\ \times x^{2} + 15\ \times x$

10,000 x2 +30x – 32 = 0

 ⇒ 5000x2 + 15x − 16 = 0

$\therefore x = \ \frac{15 \pm \ \sqrt{{(15)}^{2} - 4 \times (5000)( - 16)}}{2 \times 5000}$ = 0.055m = 5.5 cm.

question.text:
The maximum & minimum tension in the string of
simple pendulum rotating in vertical circle of radius 5m are in the

A body just being revolved in a vertical circle of radius R with a uniform speed. The string breaks when the body is at the highest point. The horizontal distance covered by the body after the string breaks is

solution.text:
As the body just completes the circular path, hence critical speed at the highest point.

$$v_{H} = \sqrt{gR}$$

which is totally horizontal.

As the string breaks at the highest point, hence form here onwards the body will follow parabolic path. Time taken by the body to reach the ground

Hence, horizontal distance covered by the body

question.text:
A roller coaster is designed such that riders experience
‘weightlessness’ as they go round the top of a hill whose radius of
curvature is 20 m. The speed of the car at the top the hill is
between

solution.text:
Balancing the force, we get

$$Mg - N = M\frac{v^{2}}{R}$$

For weightlessness, N = 0

$$\therefore\ \frac{{Mv}^{2}}{R} = Mg$$

$$or\ \ v = \sqrt{Rg}$$

Putting the values, R = 20 m, g = 10.0 ms−2

$$So,\ \ v = \sqrt{20 \times 10.0} = 14.14\ {ms}^{- 1}$$

Thus, the speed of the car at the top of the hill is between 14 ms−1 and 10 ms−1

.

question.text: A stone is tied to one end of a light inextensible string of length l and made to rotate on a vertical circle keeping other end of the string at the centre. If speed of stone at the highest point is $\left( v > \sqrt{gl} \right)$ then its speed at the lowest point is

solution.text:
Applying energy conservation

$\frac{1}{2}{mu}^{2} = mgl + \frac{1}{2}{mv}^{2}$

We get $v = \sqrt{u^{2} - 2gl}$

In vector form we can express as v=$\sqrt{u^{2} - 2gl}\ j\ and\ u = \mu_{i}$

Difference is $- u = \sqrt{\left( u^{2} + v^{2} \right)} = \sqrt{\left( 2\left( u^{2} - gl \right) \right)}$

 = 0.6 × 2 = 1.2kg

$h = \frac{0.6 + 0}{2} = 0.3m$

Hence, work done in pulling the chain on the table = work done against gravity force

W = mgh = 1.2 × 10 × 0.3 = 3.6 J.

question.text: A running man has the same kinetic energy as that of a boy of half his mass. The man speed up by 2 ms−1 and the boy changes his speed by x ms−1, so that the kinetic energies of the boy and the man are again equal. Then x in ms−1 is

solution.text:
Let vMis velocity of man,vBof boy, then kinetic energy according to question ,

$ie\ K = \frac{1}{2}Mv_{M}^{2} = \frac{1}{2}.\frac{M}{2}.v_{B}^{2}$

Or $v_{M}^{2} = \frac{V_{B}^{2}}{2}$

Or $\ \ \sqrt{\ 2}v_{M} = v_{B}$

When man speeds up 2 ms−1and boy changes his speed by x ms−1.Then ,

$\frac{1}{2}M\left( v_{M} + 2 \right)^{2} = \frac{1}{2} \bullet \frac{M}{2} \bullet \left( v_{B} + x \right)^{2}$

Or $\left( v_{M} + 2 \right)^{2} = \frac{\left( v_{B} + x \right)^{2}}{2}$

$2\left( v_{M} + 2 \right)^{2} = \left( \sqrt{2}v_{M} + x \right)^{2}$ $\left( \because v_{B} = \sqrt{2}v_{m} \right)$

Or $\sqrt{2}\left( v_{M} + 2 \right) = \sqrt{2}v_{M} + x$

Or +$2\sqrt{2} = x$

question.text:
A motor is used to deliver water at a certain rate
through a given horizontal pipe. To deliver n-times the water through
the same time the power of the motor must be increased as follows

solution.text:
The mass of the water flowing out per second

m = Avp …(i)

Where p=density of water

A=area of cross-section of pipe.

V= velocity of water

Rate of increase of kinetic energy

$= \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} = \frac{1}{2}(Avp)v^{2}$ …(ii)

Mass m, flowing out per second, can be increasing to m’ by increasing v to v’, then power increase from P to P’.

$\ \ \frac{P^{'}}{P} = \frac{\frac{1}{2}A^{'}pV^{'3}}{\frac{1}{2}Apv^{3}}\ or\frac{P^{'}}{P} = \left( \frac{v^{'}}{v} \right)^{3}$

Now, $\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \frac{m^{'}}{m} = \frac{Apv^{'}}{Apv} = \frac{v^{'}}{v}$

As,           m′ = nm, v′ = nv

$\therefore\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \frac{P^{'}}{P} = n^{3}\ \Rightarrow P^{'} = n^{3}P$

question.text: Two rectangular blocks A and B of masses 2kg and 3 kg respectively are connected by spring of spring constant 10.8 Nm−1 and are placed on a frictionless horizontal surface. The block A was given an initial velocity of 0.15 ms−1 in the direction shown in the figure. The maximum compression of the spring during the motion is

solution.text:
As the block A moves with velocity with velocity 0.15 ms−1, it compresses the spring Which pushes B towards right. A goes on compressing the spring till the velocity acquired by B becomes equal to the velocity of A, i.e. 0.15 ms−1. Let this velocity be v. Now, spring is in a state of maximum compression. Let x be the maximum compression at this stage.

According to the law of conservation of linear momentum, we get

mAu = (mA+mB)v

Or $v = \frac{m_{A}u}{m_{A} + m_{B}}$

$\frac{2 \times 0.15}{2 + 3} = 0.06ms^{- 1}$

According to the law of conservation of energy

$\frac{1}{2}m_{A}u^{2} = \frac{1}{2}\left( m_{A} + m_{B} \right)V^{2} + \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

$\frac{1}{2}m_{A}u^{2} - \frac{1}{2}\left( m_{A} + m_{B} \right)v^{2} = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

$\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times (0.15)^{2} - \frac{1}{2}(2 + 3)(0.06)^{2} = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

$0.0225 - 0.009 = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

$or\ 0.0135 = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

Or $x = \sqrt{\frac{0.0027}{k}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.0027}{10.8}}\ = 0.05m$

question.text:
A circular disc is to be made by using iron and
aluminium so that it acquired maximum moment of inertia about
geometrical axis. It is possible with

d.text: aluminium at interior and iron surround to it
iron at interior aluminium surround to it
using iron and aluminium layers in alternate order

sheet of iron is used at both external surface and aluminium sheet
as internal layers

solution.text:
A circular disc may be divided into a large number of circular rings. Moment of inertia of disc will be the summation of the moments of inertia of these rings about the geometrical axis. Now, moment of inertia of a circular ring about its geometrical axis is MR2, where M the mass is and R is the radius of the ring.

Since the density (mass per unit volume) for iron is more than that of aluminium, the proposed rings made of iron should be placed at a higher radius to get more value of MR2. Hence to get maximum moment of inertia for the circular disc, aluminium should be placed at interior and iron at the outside.

question.text: Three masses are placed on the axis : 300 g at origin, 500 g at x = 40 cm and 400 g at x = 70 cm. The distance of the centre of mass from the origin is

solution.text:
The distance of the centre of mass of the system of three masses from the origin O is

$$X_{CM} = \frac{m_{1}x_{1} + m_{2}x_{2} + m_{3}x_{3}}{m_{1} + m_{2} + m_{3}}$$

$$= \frac{300 \times 0 + 500 \times 40 + 400 \times 70}{300 + 500 + 400}$$

$$= \frac{500 \times 40 + 400 \times 70}{1200} = \frac{400\lbrack 50 + 70\rbrack}{1200}$$

$= \frac{50 + 70}{3} = \frac{120}{3} = 40\ cm$

question.text: A rod of weight W is supported by two parallel knife edges A and B and is in equilibrium in a horizontal position. The knives are at a distance d from each other. The centre of mass of the rod is at distance x from A. The normal reaction on A is

W= Weight of the rod

In vertical equilibrium,

N1 + N2 = W

Torque balance about centre of mass of the rod,

N1x = N2(d−x)

Putting value of N2 from equation (i)

N1x = (W−N1)(d−x)

 ⇒ N1x = Wd − Wx − N1d + N1x

$\Rightarrow N_{1} = \frac{w(d - x)}{d}$

question.text:
The effect of rotation of the earth on the value of
acceleration due to gravity is

d.text: g is maximum at the equator and maximum at the poles
g is minimum at the equator and maximum at the poles
g is maximum at the both poles
g is minimum at the both poles

solution.text:
As  g′ = g − ω2R cos2 λ

The latitude at point on the surface of the earth is defined as the angle, which the line joining that point to the centre of earth makes with equatorial plane. It is denoted by λ. For the poles λ = 90∘ and for equator λ = 0∘.

(i) Substituting λ = 90∘ in the above expression, we get

                       gpole = g − ω2Rcos2 90∘

∴                  gpole = g

ie, there is no effect of rotational motion of the earth on the value of g at the poles.

(ii) Substituting λ = 0∘ in the above expression, we get

                  gequator = g − ω2Rcos2 0∘

∴              gequator = g − ω2R

ie, the effect of rotation of the earth on the value of g at the equator is maximum.

question.text:
The length of an elastic string is ‘a’ metres when the

solution.text:
Let L is the original length of the wire and k is force constant of wire. Final length = initial length + elongation

$L^{'} = L + \frac{F}{k}$

For first condition a ​ $= L + \frac{4}{k}\ \ \ \ \ldots\ldots\ldots(i)$

For second condition b a ​ $= L + \frac{5}{k}\ldots\ldots(ii)$

By solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

L$= 5a - 4b\ and\ k = \frac{1}{b - a}$

Now, when the longitudinal tension is 9N. Length of the string.

$= L + \frac{9}{k} = 5a - 4b + 9(b - a)$

 = 5b − 4a

solution.text:
According to question,

$\frac{\mathcal{l}_{s}}{\mathcal{l}_{b}} = a,\ \frac{r_{s}}{r_{b}} = b,\ \frac{y_{s}}{y_{b}} = c,\ \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}\mathcal{l}_{s}}{\mathrm{\Delta}\mathcal{l}_{b}} = \ ?$

As, y = $\frac{F\mathcal{l}}{A\mathcal{\mathrm{\Delta}l}}$ ⇒ Δ𝓁 = $\frac{F\mathcal{l}}{Ay}$

$\mathrm{\Delta}\mathcal{l}_{s} = \frac{3mg\mathcal{l}_{s}}{\pi r_{s}^{2}.y_{s}}\ \ \ \ \lbrack\because F_{s} = (M + 2M)g\rbrack$

$\mathrm{\Delta}\mathcal{l}_{b} = \frac{2mg\mathcal{l}_{b}}{\pi r_{b}^{2}.y_{b}}\ \ \ \ \lbrack\because F_{b} = 2Mg\rbrack$

question.text: As shown in the figure, forces of 105N each are applied in opposite directions, on the upper and lower faces of a cube of side 10cm, shifting the upper face parallel to itself by 0.5cm. If the side of another cube of the same material is, 20cm, then under similar conditions as above, the displacement will be:

solution.text:
For same material the ratio of stress to strain is same

For first cube

Stress1 = $\frac{{force}_{1}}{{area}_{1}} = \frac{10^{5}}{(0.1)^{2}}$

Strain1 = $\frac{change\ in\ {length}_{1}}{original\ {length}_{1}} = \frac{0.5 \times 10^{- 2}}{0.1}$

For second block,

Stress2 = = $\frac{{force}_{2}}{{area}_{2}} = \frac{10^{5}}{(0.2)^{2}}$

Strain2 = $\frac{change\ in\ {length}_{2}}{original\ {length}_{2}} = \frac{x}{0.2}$

x is the displacement for second block.

For same material, $\frac{{stress}_{1}}{{strain}_{1}} = \ \frac{{stress}_{2}}{{strain}_{2}}$

Or, $\frac{\frac{10.5}{{(0.1)}^{2}}}{\frac{0.5 \times 10^{- 2}}{0.1}} = \frac{\frac{10^{5}}{{(0.2)}^{2}}}{\frac{x}{0.2}}$

Solving we get, x = 0.25 cm

question.text: A solid sphere of radius r made of a soft material of bulk modulus K is surrounded by a liquid in a cylindrical container. A massless piston of area a float on the surface of the liquid, covering entire cross-section of cylindrical container. When a mass m is placed on the surface of the piston to compress the liquid, the fractional decrement in the radius of the sphere $\left( \frac{dr}{r} \right)$, is:

solution.text:
Bulk modulus, K = $\frac{volumetric\ stress}{volumetric\ strain}$

K = $\frac{mg}{a\left( \frac{dV}{V} \right)}$

⇒ $\frac{dV}{V} = \frac{mg}{Ka}$ ….(i)

Volume of sphere, V = $\frac{4}{3}\pi R^{3}$

Fractional change in volume $\frac{dV}{V} = \frac{3dr}{r}$ …(ii)

Using eq (i) and (ii) $\frac{3dr}{r}$ = $\frac{mg}{Ka}$

$\therefore\frac{dr}{r} = \frac{mg}{3Ka}$ (fractional decrement in radius)

question.text: A vessel of area of cross-section A has liquid to a height H. There is a hole at the bottom of vessel having area of cross-section a. The time taken to decrease the level from H1 to H2 will be

solution.text:
At the height h the rate of discharge of liquid through hole at bottom is $\sqrt{2gh} \times a$

(by Bernoulli’s principal)

Let in time dt time level of water in tank decreases by dh.

Equating volumes, $Ad = dt\sqrt{2gh\ } \times a$

$\Rightarrow dt = \frac{A}{a\sqrt{2g}}\frac{dh}{\sqrt{h}}$

Integrating above we get,

$\int_{0}^{t}{dt} = \frac{A}{a\sqrt{2g}}\ \int_{H_{2}}^{H_{1}}\frac{dh}{\sqrt{h}}$

$$\Rightarrow t = \frac{A}{a\sqrt{2g}}\frac{h^{1/2}}{1/2}\left| \begin{matrix} H_{1} \\ H_{2} \end{matrix} = \frac{A}{a}\sqrt{2/g}\left\lbrack \sqrt{H_{1}} - \sqrt{H_{2}} \right\rbrack \right.\ $$

question.text: Two solid spheres of same metal but of mass M and 8M fall simultaneously on a viscous liquid and their terminal velocities are v and nv, then value of n is

solution.text:
Mass = Volume × Density $\Rightarrow M = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^{3} \times \rho$

As the density remains constant

∴ M ∝ r3

$\therefore\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} = \left( \frac{M_{1}}{M_{2}} \right)^{1/3} = \left( \frac{M}{8M} \right)^{1/3} = \frac{1}{2}$ …(i)

Terminal velocity, $v_{T} = \frac{2}{9}\frac{r^{2}(\rho - \sigma)g}{\eta}$

Where, r= radius of a spherical body

ρ= density of the material of body

σ= coefficient of viscosity of the medium

As ρ, σ, η remain constant

$$\therefore v_{T} \propto r^{2},\ \therefore\frac{v_{T_{1}}}{v_{T_{2}}} = \left( \frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} \right)^{2}$$

$\frac{v}{nv} = \left( \frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} \right)^{2}$ or $\frac{1}{n} = \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)^{2}$ [Using (i)]

or n = 4

question.text: The heat evolved for the rise of water when one end of the capillary tube of radius r is immersed vertically into water is (Assume surface tension =T and density of water = ρ)

solution.text:
$Water\ rise\ to\ height\ h = \frac{2T}{\rho g\ r}\ \ \ $

Potential energy of water column

$U = \frac{mgh}{2} = 2\pi T^{2}/\rho g$

The work performed by force of surface tension is

$W = 2\pi r\ T\ h = \frac{4\pi T^{2}}{\rho g}$

From conversation of energy the heat evolved

question.text:
A temperature of 100°F (Fahrenheit scale) is equal to T
K (Kelvin scale). The value of T is:

At what temperature do both the Centigrade and
Fahrenheit thermometers show the same reading

solution.text:
The formulas for converting between degree Celsius and degree Fahrenheit are:

°F = (°C ∗ 9/5) + 32

°C = (°F − 32) ∗ 5/9

To find the temperature when both are equal, we use an old algebra trick and just set ºF = ºC and solve one of the equations.

°C = (°C ∗ 9/5) + 32

°C − (°C ∗ 9/5) = 32

−4/5 ∗ °C = 32

°C = −32 ∗ 5/4

°C = −40

°F = (°F ∗ 9/5) + 32

°F − (°F ∗ 9/5) = 32

−4/5 ∗ °F = 32

°F = −32∗5/4

°F = −40

So the temperature when both the Celsius and Fahrenheit scales are the same is −40degrees.

The coefficient of volume expansion of a liquid is 49 × 10−5K−1. Calculate the fractional change in its density when the temperature is raised by 30℃.

solution.text:
Variations of density with temperature is given by

$$\ \rho ’ = \ \frac{\rho}{1 + \gamma\mathrm{\Delta}\theta}$$

solution.text:
Here, $\frac{50}{100}\ (KE$ of rotation) = c m θ

$\frac{1}{2}\left( \frac{1}{2}I\omega^{2} \right) = cm\theta\frac{1}{4}(\frac{2}{5}Ir^{2}\ )(2\pi n\ )^{2} = cm\theta$

question.text: The three rods shown in figure have identical dimensions. Heat flows from the hot end at a rate of 40 W in the arrangement (a). Find the rates of heat flow when the rods are joined as in arrangement (b). (Assume KAl=200 W/m °C and KCu= 400 W/m °C)

solution.text:
(a)

∵ The rods have identical dimensions.

Let their area of cross-section be = A and length be = L

So each rod would have heat resistance of $R = \frac{L}{KA}$

Reff. = R1 + R2 + R3

$= \frac{L}{K_{Al}A} + \frac{L}{K_{Cu}A} + \frac{L}{K_{Al}A}$

Reff. = $\frac{L}{A} \times \frac{5}{400}\ $ [∵KAl = 200.,  KCu = 400 ]

$H_{1} = \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}T}{R_{eff}} = \frac{100}{\frac{L}{A} \times \frac{5}{400}}$ … (1)

(b) When rods are connected in parallel

$\frac{1}{R_{eff}} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} + \frac{1}{R_{2}} + \frac{1}{R_{3}}$

Reff. = $\frac{L}{A} \times \ 800$

$H_{1} = \frac{100}{\frac{L}{A} \times \ 800\ }$ … (2)

Dividing (2) by (1)

$\frac{40}{H_{2}} = \frac{400}{800 \times 5}$ ⇒ H2 = 400 W

question.text:

solution.text:
Change in internal energy is path independent and depends only on the initial and final states. As the initial and final states in the three processes are same. Therefore,

ΔU1 = ΔU2 = ΔU3

Workdone, W = Area under P-V graph

As area under curve 1 > area under curve 2 > area under curve 3

∴ W1 > W2 > W3

According to first law of thermodynamics,

Q = W + ΔU

As W1 > W2 > W3 and ΔU1 = ΔU2 = ΔU3

∴ Q1 > Q2 > Q3.

So, $\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}Q}{\mathrm{\Delta}W} = \frac{C_{P}}{R} = \frac{C_{P}}{C_{P} - C_{V}} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{C_{V}}{C_{P}}} = \frac{\gamma}{\gamma - 1}$ $\left\lbrack \frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} = \gamma \right\rbrack$

Work done on the gas = Area under P − V curve

As area under the P − V curve is maximum for adiabatic process, so work done on the gas is maximum for adiabatic process.

question.text: Three different processes that can occur in an ideal monoatomic gas are shown in the P vs V diagram. > 0, W<sub>AC</sub>=0, W<sub>AD</sub> > 0

W<sub>AB</sub> < 0, W<sub>AC</sub> < W<sub>AD</sub>

solution.text:

EAB = EAC = EAD

Work done, W = P ⋅ ⊗T

AC → volume is increasing ⇒ WAC > 0

question.text: n’ moles of an ideal gas undergoes a process A → B is shown in the figure. The maximum temperature of the gas during the process will be:

solution.text:
$P\ = \frac{{- P}_{0}}{V_{0}}V + 3P$

$\left\lbrack slope = \frac{{- P}_{0}}{V_{0}},\ c = 3P_{0}\ \ \right\rbrack$

PV0 + P0V = 3P0V0 …. (i)

But pV = nRT

∴ p = $\frac{nRT}{V}$ …. (ii)

∴ nRT V0 + P0V2 = 3P0V0V …. (iii)

For temperature to be maximum $\frac{dT}{dV} = 0$

Differentiating eq.(iii) by ‘V’ we get

nRV0$\frac{dT}{dV}$ + P0(2V) = 3P0V0

∴ nRV0$\frac{dT}{dV}$ =3P0V0 – 2P0V

$\frac{dT}{dV}$ = $\frac{3P_{0}V_{0} - 2P_{0}V}{{nRV}_{0}} = 0$

$\ V = \frac{3V_{0}}{2}$ ∴ $P = \frac{3P_{0}}{2}$ [From (i)]

question.text:
5.6 litre of helium gas at STP is adiabatically
compressed 0.7 litre. Taking the initial temperature is T<sub>1</sub>,
the work done in the process is:

solution.text:
Initially, volume V1 = 5.6l , temperature =T1 and  = $\frac{5}{3}$ (for monoatomic gas)

The number of moles of gas, $n = \frac{5.6l}{22.4l} = \frac{1}{4}$

Finally (after adiabatic compression) V2 = 0.7l

For adiabatic process T1V1−1 = T2V2−1

∴ $T_{2} = T_{1}\left( \frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}} \right)^{- 1}$ = $T_{1}\left( \frac{5.6}{0.7} \right)^{\frac{5}{3} - 1}$

= T1(8)2/3 = 4T1

Work done in adiabatic process

$W = \frac{nRT}{- 1} = \frac{\frac{1}{4}R\left\lbrack T_{1} - {4T}_{1} \right\rbrack}{\left\lbrack \frac{5}{3} - 1 \right\rbrack}$ = $\frac{9}{8}RT_{1}$

question.text: Under the adiabatic process, the volume of ideal gas gets doubled. Consequently the mean collision time between the gas molecule changes from t1 to t2 . If $\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} = \gamma$ for this gas then a good estimate for $\frac{t_{2}}{t_{1}}$ is given by:

solution.text:
We know that Relaxation time,

T ∝ $\frac{V}{\sqrt{T}}$ …. (i)

Equation of adiabatic process is

TV+1 = constant

⇒ T∝ $\frac{1}{V^{+ 1}}$

⇒ $T\ V^{1 + \frac{- 1}{2}}$ using (i)

⇒ $T\ V^{\frac{1 + \ }{2}}$

⇒ $\frac{T_{f}}{T_{i}} = \left( \frac{V}{2V} \right)^{\frac{1 + \ }{2}}$ = ${\ \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)}^{\frac{\gamma + 1\ }{2}}$

question.text: An ideal expands isothermally from a volume V1to V2and then compressed to original volume V1adiabatically. Initial pressure is p1and final pressure is p3. The total work done is W. Then

solution.text:
Let the thermodynamic coordinates of various states be:
$${initial\ state\ \left( P_{1},V_{1},T_{1} \right) }{state\ after\ first\ process\ \left( P_{2},V_{2},T_{2} \right) }{final\ \ state\ \left( P_{3},V_{3},T_{3} \right) }{First\ process\ being\ isothermal,\ P_{2} = \frac{ P_{1} V_{1}}{V_{2}} }{and\ T_{2} = T_{1} }{Next\ one\ being\ adiabatic,\ P_{2} V_{2}^{\gamma} = P_{3} V_{3}^{\gamma} }{Here\ V_{3} = V_{1} }{So\ \ \ P_{3} = \frac{P_{2}V_{2}^{\gamma}}{ V_{1}^{\gamma}} }{Replacing\ P2\ from\ above,P_{3} = P_{1}\frac{ V_{2}^{\gamma - 1}}{V_{1}^{\gamma - 1}} }{We\ know\ that\ \gamma > 1 \Rightarrow \gamma - 1 > 0 }{given\ V_{2} > V_{1} \Rightarrow \left( \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \right)^{\gamma - 1} > 1 }{Hence\ P_{3} > P_{1} }{Work\ done\ in\ first\ process = P_{1} V_{1} ln\left( \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \right)}$$

$${= \frac{P_{1} V_{1}}{\gamma - 1}\ \ ln{(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}})}^{\gamma - 1} < P_{1} V_{1}\frac{{\left( \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \right)}^{\gamma - 1} - 1}{\gamma - 1} }{and\ in\ second\ process\ work = \ \frac{P_{2} V_{2} - P_{3} V_{1}}{\gamma - 1} = P_{1} V_{1}\frac{1 - \left( \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \right)^{\gamma - 1}}{\gamma - 1} }{Hence\ net\ work = W < 0}$$

question.text: The speeds of 5 molecules of a gas (in arbitrary units) are as follows: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. The root mean square speed for these molecules is

question.text: The rms velocity of gas molecules is 300 ms−1. The rms velocity of molecules of gas with twice the molecular weight and half the absolute temperature is

question.text: The r.m.s. speed of the molecules of a gas at a pressure 105Pa and temperature 0℃ is 0.5km sec−1. If the pressure is kept constant but temperature is raised to 819℃, the velocity will become

question.text: Consider a mixture of n moles of helium gas and 2n moles of oxygen gas (molecules taken to be rigid) as an ideal gas. Its CP/CV value will be:

solution.text:
Helium is a monoatomic gas and Oxygen is a diatomic gas.

For helium, $C_{V_{1}} = \frac{3}{2}R$ and $C_{P_{1}} = \frac{5}{2}R$

For oxygen, $C_{V_{2}} = \frac{5}{2}R$ and $C_{P_{2}} = \frac{7}{2}R$

$= \frac{N_{1}C_{P_{1}} + N_{2}C_{P_{2}}}{{N_{1}C}_{V_{1}} + N_{2}C_{V_{2}}}$ $\ \ \ = \ \frac{n\frac{5}{2}R + 2n\frac{7}{2}R}{n\frac{3}{2}R + 2n\frac{5}{2}R}$ = $\frac{19nR2}{2(13nR)}$

$\ \ \left( \frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} \right)_{mixture} = \frac{19}{13}$

question.text: Two moles of an ideal gas with $\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} = \frac{5}{3}$ are mixed with 3 moles of another ideal gas with $\frac{C_{P}}{C_{V}} = \frac{4}{3}$ for the mixture is

solution.text:
Using $\gamma_{mixture} = \frac{n_{1}C_{P_{1}} + n_{2}C_{P_{2}}}{{n_{1}C}_{V_{1}} + n_{2}C_{V_{2}}}$

⇒ $\frac{n_{1}}{\gamma_{1} - 1} + \frac{n_{2}}{\gamma_{2} - 1}$ = $\frac{{n_{1} + n}_{2}}{\gamma_{m} - 1}$

⇒ $\frac{3}{\frac{4}{3} - 1} +$ $\frac{2}{\frac{5}{3} - 1} = \frac{5}{\gamma_{m} - 1}$

⇒ $\frac{9}{1} + \frac{23}{2} = \frac{5}{\gamma_{m} - 1}$ ⇒ $\gamma_{m} - 1 = \frac{5}{2}$

⇒ $\gamma_{m} = \frac{17}{12} = 1.42$

= 2.1R = 2.1  8.3 = 17.4 J/mol-k

question.text: Air is pumped into an automobile tube upto a pressure of 200 kPa in the morning when the air temperature is 22℃. During the day, temperature rises to 42℃ and the tube expands by 2%. The pressure of the air in the tube at this temperature, will be approximately

solution.text:
The ideal gas law is the equation of state of an ideal gas. The state of an amount of gas is determined by its pressure, volume and temperature. The equation has the form

pV = nRT

Where, p is pressure, V the volume, n the number of moles, R the gas constant and T the temperature?

$$\therefore\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \frac{p_{1}V_{1}}{T_{1}} = \frac{p_{2}V_{2}}{T_{2}}$$

Given, p1 = 200 kPa, V1 = V, T1 = 273 + 22 = 295 K, V2 = V + 0.02 V

T2 = 273 + 42 = 315 K

$\frac{200 \times V}{295} = \frac{p_{2} \times 1.02V}{315}$

$\Rightarrow \ \ \ \ p_{2} = \frac{200 \times 315}{295 \times 1.02}$

p2 = 209 kPa.

question.text: The temperature of an open room of volume 30cm3 increases from 170C to 270C due to sunshine. The atmospheric pressure in the room remains 1 × 105 Pa. If ni and n f are the number of molecules in the room before and after heating, then nf – ni will be:

solution.text:
Given: Temperature Ti = 17 + 273 = 290 K

Temperature Tf = 27 + 273 = 300 K

Atmosphere pressure P0 = 1  105 Pa

Volume of room, V0 = 30 m3

Difference in number of molecules, nf – ni = ?

Using ideal gas equation, PV = nRT(V0)

N0 = Avogadro’s number

⇒ $n = \frac{PV}{RT}\left( V_{0} \right)$

∴ $n_{f} - n_{i} = \frac{P_{0}V_{0}}{R}\left( \frac{1}{T_{f}} - \frac{1}{T_{i}} \right)N_{0}$

= $\frac{110^{5}30}{8.314}6.02310^{23}\left( \frac{1}{300} - \frac{1}{290} \right)$

=  − 2.5 1025

$= \frac{\sqrt{2}2006.02310^{23}}{2.510^{- 3}}.\ 10^{- 18}0.09$

The closest value in the given option is = 1010

question.text: In an ideal gas at temperature T, the average force that a molecule applies on the walls of a closed container depends at T and Tq. A good estimate for q is:

solution.text:
Energy associated with N moles of diatomic gas

$U_{i} = N\frac{5}{2}RT$

Energy associated with N moles of monatomic gas

$= N\frac{3}{2}RT$

Total energy when a moles of diatomic gas converted into monoatomic

$U_{i} = 2n\frac{3}{2}RT + (N - n)\frac{5}{2}RT$

$= \frac{1}{2}nRT + \frac{5}{2}NRT$

Now, change in total kinetic energy of the gas

$U = Q = \frac{1}{2}nRT$

question.text: Consider two ideal diatomic gases A and B at same temperature T. Molecules of the gas A are rigid, and have a mass m. Molecules of the gas B have an additional vibrational mode, and have a mass $\frac{m}{4}$​. The ratio of the specific heats (CVA​ and CVB​) of gas A and B, respectively is?

solution.text:
Specific heat of gas at constant volume

Cv = $\frac{1}{2}$ f R, f = degree of freedom

For gas A (diatomic)

f = 5(3 translational + 2 rotational)

∴$\ C_{v}^{A} = \frac{5}{2}R$

For gas B (diatomic) in addition to (3 translational + 2 rotational)

2 vibrational degree of freedom.

∴$\ C_{v}^{B} = \frac{7}{2}R$. Hence $\frac{C_{v}^{A}}{C_{v}^{B}} = \frac{\frac{5}{2}R}{\frac{7}{2}R} = \frac{5}{7}$

question.text: A body executing simple harmonic motion has a maximum acceleration equal to 24 ms−2 and maximum velocity of 16 ms−1, the amplitude of the simple harmonic motion is

solution.text:
Maximum acceleration is given by

 = aω2 = 24 ms−2 …(i)

Maximum velocity

= aω = 16 ms−2 …(ii)

Dividing Eq. (i) by Eq. (ii)

$$\frac{a\omega^{2}}{a\omega} = \omega = \frac{24}{16} = \frac{6}{4} = \frac{3}{2}$$

Now putting the value of ω in Eq. (ii), we get

$$a \times \frac{3}{2} = 16$$

$a = \frac{32}{3}$ m

question.text: A particle moves so that its acceleration a is given by a =  − bx, where x is displacement from equilibrium position and b is a non-negative real constant. The time period of oscillation of the particle is

solution.text:
The relation between acceleration (a) and displacement (x) for a body in SHM is

a =  − ω2x

Given, a =  − bx

On comparing the two equations, we get

ω2 = b

∴ $\omega = \sqrt{b}$

Since, $\omega = \frac{2\pi}{T}$

∴ $\frac{2\pi}{T} = \sqrt{b}$

$\Rightarrow \ T = \frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{b}}$.

At t=4 s or after 2 s from mean position.

or $4 = \left( \frac{2\pi}{16} \right)\sqrt{a^{2} - \frac{a^{2}}{2}}$

[From Eq. (i)]

$T = 8\pi\sqrt{\frac{k_{1} + k_{2}}{k_{1}k_{2}}}$

question.text: A particle performs simple harmonic motion with amplitude A. Its speed is tripled at the instant that it is at a distance $\frac{2A}{3}$ from equilibrium position. The new amplitude of the motion is:

solution.text:
We know that $V\ = \sqrt{A^{2} - x^{2}}$

Initially, $V\ = \sqrt{A^{2} - \left( \frac{2A}{3} \right)^{2}}$

Finally, $3V\ = \sqrt{A^{2} - \left( \frac{2A}{3} \right)^{2}}\ \ $

Where A′ = final amplitude (given at $x = \frac{2A}{3}$, velocity to trebled)

On dividing we get

$\frac{3}{\ \ \ 1} = \frac{\sqrt{A^{2} - \left( \frac{2A}{3} \right)^{2}}}{\sqrt{A^{2} - \left( \frac{2A}{3} \right)^{2}}}$

$9\left\lbrack A^{2} - \frac{{4A}^{2}}{9} \right\rbrack$ = $A^{2} - \frac{{4A}^{2}}{9}$ ∴ $A = \frac{7A}{3}$

solution.text:
Potential energy of spring =$\frac{1}{2}kx^{2}$

Here, x = distance of block from mean position

At mean position, potential energy = $\frac{1}{2}kA^{2}$

As equilibrium position, half of the mass of block breaks off, so its potential energy becomes half.

question.text: When a particle of mass m is attached to a vertical spring of spring constant k and released, its motion is described by y (t) = y0 sin2 ωt, where ‘y’ is measured from the lower end of upstretched spring. Then ω is:

solution.text:
y = y0 sin2 ωt

⇒ $y = \frac{y_{0}}{2}(1 - \cos^{2}t)$ $\left( \because\ \ \ \sin^{2}t = \ \frac{1 - \sin^{2}t}{2} \right)$

⇒ $y - \frac{y_{0}}{2} = \frac{{- y}_{0}}{2}\cos cos\ 2t\ \ $

⇒ y  = Acos cos 2t  

∴ Amplitude = $\frac{y_{0}}{2}$

Angular velocity = 2ω

For equilibrium of mass, $\frac{{ky}_{0}}{2} = mg\ \ $⇒ $\frac{k}{m}$ = $\frac{2g}{y_{0}}$

Also, spring constant k = m(2ω)2

⇒ 2ω = $\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} = \sqrt{\frac{2g}{y_{0}}}$

⇒ ω = $\frac{1}{2}$ $\sqrt{\frac{2g}{y_{0}}}$ =$\sqrt{\frac{g}{y_{0}}}$

question.text: If the phase difference between two sound waves of wavelength λ is 60o, the corresponding path difference is

solution.text:
Path difference for a given phase difference δ is given by

$$\mathrm{\Delta}x = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi}\delta$$

Given that $\delta = 60{^\circ} = \frac{\pi}{3}$

$\Delta x = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi} \times \frac{\pi}{3}\ \therefore\mathrm{\Delta}x = \frac{\lambda}{6}$.

v1 and v2 are the velocities of sound at the same temperature in two monoatomic gases of densities ρ1 and ρ2 respectively. If $\rho_{1}/\rho_{2} = \frac{1}{4}$ then the ratio of velocities v1 and v2 will be

solution.text:
At given temperature and pressure

$v \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{\rho}} \Rightarrow \frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}} = \sqrt{\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{1}}} = \sqrt{\frac{4}{1}} = 2\ :1$ .

question.text: When the temperature of an ideal gas is increased by 600 K, the velocity of sound in the gas becomes $\sqrt{3}$ times the initial velocity in it. The initial temperature of the gas is

solution.text:
By using $v = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma RT}{M}} \Rightarrow v \propto \sqrt{T}$

$\frac{v_{2}}{v_{1}} = \sqrt{\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}} = \sqrt{\frac{T + 600}{T}} = \sqrt{3} \Rightarrow T = 300\ K = 27℃$.

question.text:
If the temperature is raised by 1 K from 300 K the
percentage change in the speed of sound in the gaseous mixture is
(R=8.31 J/mol-K)

solution.text:
From $v = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma RT}{M}}$

$$\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}v}{v} = \frac{1}{2}\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}T}{T}$$

$$\frac{\mathrm{\Delta}v}{v} \times 100 = \frac{1}{2}\left( \frac{\mathrm{\Delta}T}{T} \right) \times 100$$

$= \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{300} \times 100 = 0.167\ \%$.

Velocity of sound in a gas

$$\therefore\ \ \ \ \frac{v_{H_{2}}}{v_{H_{2}}} = \ \sqrt{\frac{\gamma_{H_{2}} \times d_{He}}{d_{H_{2}} \times \gamma_{He\ }}}$$

$$\frac{v_{H_{2}}}{v_{He}} = \sqrt{\frac{7 \times 3 \times 2}{5 \times 5}}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \left\lbrack As\frac{d_{He}}{d_{H_{2}}} = 2 \right\rbrack$$

$\therefore\frac{v_{H_{2}}}{v_{He}} = \frac{\sqrt{42}}{2}$.

question.text: A source of sound placed at the open end of a resonance column sends an acoustic wave of pressure amplitude ρ0 inside the tube. If the atmospheric pressure is ρA, then the ratio of maximum and minimum pressure at the closed end of the tube will be

solution.text:
Maximum pressure at closed end will be atmosphere pressure adding with acoustic wave pressure

So ρmax = ρA + ρ0 and ρmin = ρA − ρ0

Thus, $\frac{\rho_{\max}}{\rho_{\min}} = \frac{\rho_{A} + \rho_{0}}{\rho_{A} - \rho_{0}}$.

Equations of a stationary wave and a travelling wave are y1 = a sinkx cosωt andy2 = a sin(ωt−kx). The phase difference between two points $x_{1} = \frac{\pi}{3k}$ and $x_{2} = \frac{3\pi}{2k}$ are ϕ1 and ϕ2 respectively for the two waves. The ratio ϕ1/ϕ2is

solution.text:
Equation of stationary wave is

y1 = asin sin  kxcos cos  ωt  

And equation of progressive wave is

y2 = asin sin  (ωt−kx) 

 = a(sinsin ωtcoscos kx−coscos ωtsinsin kx    )

At $x_{1} = \frac{\pi}{3k}\ and\ x_{2} = \frac{3\pi}{2k}$

sin sin  kx1 or sin sin  kx2  is zero.

∴neitherx1 nor x2 is node.

$$\mathrm{\Delta}x = x_{1} - x_{2} = \frac{3\pi}{2k} - \frac{\pi}{3k} = \frac{7\pi}{6k}$$

As $\mathrm{\Delta}x = \frac{7\pi}{6k},$ therefore, $\frac{2\pi}{k} > \mathrm{\Delta}x > \frac{\pi}{k}$

But $\frac{2\pi}{k} = \lambda,$ so, $\lambda > \mathrm{\Delta}x > \frac{\lambda}{2}$.

In case of a stationary wave, phase difference between any two points is either zero or π.

$$\therefore\ \ \ \phi_{1} = \pi\ and\ \ \phi_{2} = k\mathrm{\Delta}x = k\frac{7\pi}{6k} = \frac{7}{6}\pi$$

$\therefore\ \ \frac{\phi_{1}}{\phi_{2}} = \frac{\pi}{\frac{7}{6}\pi} = \frac{6}{7}$.
